metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: DSA Dijkstra's Algorithm
Dijkstra's shortest path algorithm was invented in 1956 by the Dutch computer scientist Edsger W. Dijkstra during a twenty minutes coffee break, while out shopping with his fiancée in Amsterdam.
content.html: Dijkstra's shortest path algorithm was invented in 1956 by the Dutch computer scientist Edsger W. Dijkstra during a twenty minutes coffee break, while out shopping with his fiancée in Amsterdam.

content.text: The reason for inventing the algorithm was to test a new computer called ARMAC.
content.html: The reason for inventing the algorithm was to test a new computer called ARMAC.

content.text: Dijkstra's Algorithm
Dijkstra's algorithm finds the shortest path from one vertex to all other vertices.
content.html: Dijkstra's algorithm finds the shortest path from one vertex to all other vertices.

content.text: It does so by repeatedly selecting the nearest unvisited vertex and calculating the distance to all the unvisited neighboring vertices.
content.html: It does so by repeatedly selecting the nearest unvisited vertex and calculating the distance to all the unvisited neighboring vertices.

content.text: Dijkstra's algorithm is often considered to be the most straightforward algorithm for solving the shortest path problem.
content.html: Dijkstra's algorithm is often considered to be the most straightforward algorithm for solving the shortest path problem.

content.text: Dijkstra's algorithm is used for solving single-source shortest path problems for directed or undirected paths. Single-source means that one vertex is chosen to be the start, and the algorithm will find the shortest path from that vertex to all other vertices.
content.html: Dijkstra's algorithm is used for solving single-source shortest path problems for directed or undirected paths. Single-source means that one vertex is chosen to be the start, and the algorithm will find the shortest path from that vertex to all other vertices.

content.text: Dijkstra's algorithm does not work for graphs with negative edges. For graphs with negative edges, the Bellman-Ford algorithm that is described on the next page, can be used instead.
content.html: Dijkstra's algorithm does not work for graphs with negative edges. For graphs with negative edges, the Bellman-Ford algorithm that is described on the next page, can be used instead.

content.text: To find the shortest path, Dijkstra's algorithm needs to know which vertex is the source, it needs a way to mark vertices as visited, and it needs an overview of the current shortest distance to each vertex as it works its way through the graph, updating these distances when a shorter distance is found.
content.html: To find the shortest path, Dijkstra's algorithm needs to know which vertex is the source, it needs a way to mark vertices as visited, and it needs an overview of the current shortest distance to each vertex as it works its way through the graph, updating these distances when a shorter distance is found.

content.text: How it works:
content.html: How it works:

content.text: In the animation above, when a vertex is marked as visited, the vertex and its edges become faded to indicate that Dijkstra's algorithm is now done with that vertex, and will not visit it again.
content.html: In the animation above, when a vertex is marked as visited, the vertex and its edges become faded to indicate that Dijkstra's algorithm is now done with that vertex, and will not visit it again.

content.text: Note: This basic version of Dijkstra's algorithm gives us the value of the shortest path cost to every vertex, but not what the actual path is. So for example, in the animation above, we get the shortest path cost value 10 to vertex F, but the algorithm does not give us which vertices (D-> E-> C-> D-> F) that make up this shortest path. We will add this functionality further down here on this page.
content.html: Note: This basic version of Dijkstra's algorithm gives us the value of the shortest path cost to every vertex, but not what the actual path is. So for example, in the animation above, we get the shortest path cost value 10 to vertex F, but the algorithm does not give us which vertices (D->E->C->D->F) that make up this shortest path. We will add this functionality further down here on this page.

content.text: A Detailed Dijkstra Simulation
Run the simulation below to get a more detailed understanding of how Dijkstra's algorithm runs on a specific graph, finding the shortest distances from vertex D.
content.html: Run the simulation below to get a more detailed understanding of how Dijkstra's algorithm runs on a specific graph, finding the shortest distances from vertex D.

content.text: This simulation shows how distances are calculated from vertex D to all other vertices, by always choosing the next vertex to be the closest unvisited vertex from the starting point.
content.html: This simulation shows how distances are calculated from vertex D to all other vertices, by always choosing the next vertex to be the closest unvisited vertex from the starting point.

content.text: Follow the step-by-step description below to get all the details of how Dijkstra's algorithm calculates the shortest distances.
content.html: Follow the step-by-step description below to get all the details of how Dijkstra's algorithm calculates the shortest distances.

content.text: Manual Run Through
Consider the Graph below.
content.html: Consider the Graph below.

content.text: We want to find the shortest path from the source vertex D to all other vertices, so that for example the shortest path to C is D-> E-> C, with path weight 2+4=6.
content.html: We want to find the shortest path from the source vertex D to all other vertices, so that for example the shortest path to C is D->E->C, with path weight 2+4=6.

content.text: To find the shortest path, Dijkstra's algorithm uses an array with the distances to all other vertices, and initially sets these distances to infinite, or a very big number. And the distance to the vertex we start from (the source) is set to 0.
content.html: To find the shortest path, Dijkstra's algorithm uses an array with the distances to all other vertices, and initially sets these distances to infinite, or a very big number. And the distance to the vertex we start from (the source) is set to 0.

content.code_html:
distances = [inf, inf, inf, 0, inf, inf, inf]
#vertices   [ A ,  B ,  C , D,  E ,  F ,  G ]

content.text: The image below shows the initial infinite distances to other vertices from the starting vertex D. The distance value for vertex D is 0 because that is the starting point.
content.html: The image below shows the initial infinite distances to other vertices from the starting vertex D. The distance value for vertex D is 0 because that is the starting point.

content.text: Dijkstra's algorithm then sets vertex D as the current vertex, and looks at the distance to the adjacent vertices. Since the initial distance to vertices A and E is infinite, the new distance to these are updated with the edge weights. So vertex A gets the distance changed from inf to 4, and vertex E gets the distance changed to 2. As mentioned on the previous page, updating the distance values in this way is called 'relaxing'.
content.html: Dijkstra's algorithm then sets vertex D as the current vertex, and looks at the distance to the adjacent vertices. Since the initial distance to vertices A and E is infinite, the new distance to these are updated with the edge weights. So vertex A gets the distance changed from inf to 4, and vertex E gets the distance changed to 2. As mentioned on the previous page, updating the distance values in this way is called 'relaxing'.

content.text: After relaxing vertices A and E, vertex D is considered visited, and will not be visited again.
content.html: After relaxing vertices A and E, vertex D is considered visited, and will not be visited again.

content.text: The next vertex to be chosen as the current vertex must the vertex with the shortest distance to the source vertex (vertex D), among the previously unvisited vertices. Vertex E is therefore chosen as the current vertex after vertex D.
content.html: The next vertex to be chosen as the current vertex must the vertex with the shortest distance to the source vertex (vertex D), among the previously unvisited vertices. Vertex E is therefore chosen as the current vertex after vertex D.

content.text: The distance to all adjacent and not previously visited vertices from vertex E must now be calculated, and updated if needed.
content.html: The distance to all adjacent and not previously visited vertices from vertex E must now be calculated, and updated if needed.

content.text: The calculated distance from D to vertex A, via E, is 2+4=6. But the current distance to vertex A is already 4, which is lower, so the distance to vertex A is not updated.
content.html: The calculated distance from D to vertex A, via E, is 2+4=6. But the current distance to vertex A is already 4, which is lower, so the distance to vertex A is not updated.

content.text: The distance to vertex C is calculated to be 2+4=6, which is less than infinity, so the distance to vertex C is updated.
content.html: The distance to vertex C is calculated to be 2+4=6, which is less than infinity, so the distance to vertex C is updated.

content.text: Similarly, the distance to node G is calculated and updated to be 2+5=7.
content.html: Similarly, the distance to node G is calculated and updated to be 2+5=7.

content.text: The next vertex to be visited is vertex A because it has the shortest distance from D of all the unvisited vertices.
content.html: The next vertex to be visited is vertex A because it has the shortest distance from D of all the unvisited vertices.

content.text: The calculated distance to vertex C, via A, is 4+3=7, which is higher than the already set distance to vertex C, so the distance to vertex C is not updated.
content.html: The calculated distance to vertex C, via A, is 4+3=7, which is higher than the already set distance to vertex C, so the distance to vertex C is not updated.

content.text: Vertex A is now marked as visited, and the next current vertex is vertex C because that has the lowest distance from vertex D between the remaining unvisited vertices.
content.html: Vertex A is now marked as visited, and the next current vertex is vertex C because that has the lowest distance from vertex D between the remaining unvisited vertices.

content.text: Vertex F gets updated distance 6+5=11, and vertex B gets updated distance 6+2=8.
content.html: Vertex F gets updated distance 6+5=11, and vertex B gets updated distance 6+2=8.

content.text: Calculated distance to vertex G via vertex C is 6+5=11 which is higher than the already set distance of 7, so distance to vertex G is not updated.
content.html: Calculated distance to vertex G via vertex C is 6+5=11 which is higher than the already set distance of 7, so distance to vertex G is not updated.

content.text: Vertex C is marked as visited, and the next vertex to be visited is G because is has the lowest distance between the remaining unvisited vertices.
content.html: Vertex C is marked as visited, and the next vertex to be visited is G because is has the lowest distance between the remaining unvisited vertices.

content.text: Vertex F already has a distance of 11. This is lower than the calculated distance from G, which is 7+5=12, so the distance to vertex F is not updated.
content.html: Vertex F already has a distance of 11. This is lower than the calculated distance from G, which is 7+5=12, so the distance to vertex F is not updated.

content.text: Vertex G is marked as visited, and B becomes the current vertex because it has the lowest distance of the remaining unvisited vertices.
content.html: Vertex G is marked as visited, and B becomes the current vertex because it has the lowest distance of the remaining unvisited vertices.

content.text: The new distance to F via B is 8+2=10, because it is lower than F's existing distance of 11.
content.html: The new distance to F via B is 8+2=10, because it is lower than F's existing distance of 11.

content.text: Vertex B is marked as visited, and there is nothing to check for the last unvisited vertex F, so Dijkstra's algorithm is finished.
content.html: Vertex B is marked as visited, and there is nothing to check for the last unvisited vertex F, so Dijkstra's algorithm is finished.

content.text: Every vertex has been visited only once, and the result is the lowest distance from the source vertex D to every other vertex in the graph.
content.html: Every vertex has been visited only once, and the result is the lowest distance from the source vertex D to every other vertex in the graph.

content.text: Implementation of Dijkstra's Algorithm
To implement Dijkstra's algorithm, we create a Graph class. The Graph represents the graph with its vertices and edges:
content.html: To implement Dijkstra's algorithm, we create a Graph class. The Graph represents the graph with its vertices and edges:

content.code_html:
class Graph:
    def __init__(self, size):
        self.adj_matrix = [[0] * size for _ in range(size)]
        self.size = size
        self.vertex_data = [''] * size

    def add_edge(self, u, v, weight):
        if 0 <= u < self.size and 0 <= v < self.size:
            self.adj_matrix[u][v] = weight
            self.adj_matrix[v][u] = weight  # For undirected graph

    def add_vertex_data(self, vertex, data):
        if 0 <= vertex < self.size:
            self.vertex_data[vertex] = data

content.text: Line 3: We create the adj_matrix to hold all the edges and edge weights. Initial values are set to 0 .
content.html: Line 3: We create the adj_matrix to hold all the edges and edge weights. Initial values are set to 0.

content.text: Line 4: size is the number of vertices in the graph.
content.html: Line 4: size is the number of vertices in the graph.

content.text: Line 5: The vertex_data holds the names of all the vertices.
content.html: Line 5: The vertex_data holds the names of all the vertices.

content.text: Line 7-10: The add_edge method is used to add an edge from vertex u to vertex v , with edge weight weight .
content.html: Line 7-10: The add_edge method is used to add an edge from vertex u to vertex v, with edge weight weight.

content.text: Line 12-14: The add_vertex_data method is used to add a vertex to the graph. The index where the vertex should belong is given with the vertex argument, and data is the name of the vertex.
content.html: Line 12-14: The add_vertex_data method is used to add a vertex to the graph. The index where the vertex should belong is given with the vertex argument, and data is the name of the vertex.

content.code_html:
def dijkstra(self, start_vertex_data):
        start_vertex = self.vertex_data.index(start_vertex_data)
        distances = [float('inf')] * self.size
        distances[start_vertex] = 0
        visited = [False] * self.size

        for _ in range(self.size):
            min_distance = float('inf')
            u = None
            for i in range(self.size):
                if not visited[i] and distances[i] < min_distance:
                    min_distance = distances[i]
                    u = i

            if u is None:
                break

            visited[u] = True

            for v in range(self.size):
                if self.adj_matrix[u][v] != 0 and not visited[v]:
                    alt = distances[u] + self.adj_matrix[u][v]
                    if alt < distances[v]:
                        distances[v] = alt

        return distances

content.html: Line 18-19: The initial distance is set to infinity for all vertices in the distances array, except for the start vertex, where the distance is 0.

content.text: Line 20: All vertices are initially set to False to mark them as not visited in the visited array.
content.html: Line 20: All vertices are initially set to False to mark them as not visited in the visited array.

content.text: Line 23-28: The next current vertex is found. Outgoing edges from this vertex will be checked to see if shorter distances can be found. It is the unvisited vertex with the lowest distance from the start.
content.html: Line 23-28: The next current vertex is found. Outgoing edges from this vertex will be checked to see if shorter distances can be found. It is the unvisited vertex with the lowest distance from the start.

content.text: Line 30-31: If the next current vertex has not been found, the algorithm is finished. This means that all vertices that are reachable from the source have been visited.
content.html: Line 30-31: If the next current vertex has not been found, the algorithm is finished. This means that all vertices that are reachable from the source have been visited.

content.text: Line 33: The current vertex is set as visited before relaxing adjacent vertices. This is more effective because we avoid checking the distance to the current vertex itself.
content.html: Line 33: The current vertex is set as visited before relaxing adjacent vertices. This is more effective because we avoid checking the distance to the current vertex itself.

content.text: Line 35-39: Distances are calculated for not visited adjacent vertices, and updated if the new calculated distance is lower.
content.html: Line 35-39: Distances are calculated for not visited adjacent vertices, and updated if the new calculated distance is lower.

content.code_html:
class Graph:
    def __init__(self, size):
        self.adj_matrix = [[0] * size for _ in range(size)]
        self.size = size
        self.vertex_data = [''] * size

    def add_edge(self, u, v, weight):
        if 0 <= u < self.size and 0 <= v < self.size:
            self.adj_matrix[u][v] = weight
            self.adj_matrix[v][u] = weight  # For undirected graph

    def add_vertex_data(self, vertex, data):
        if 0 <= vertex < self.size:
            self.vertex_data[vertex] = data

    def dijkstra(self, start_vertex_data):
        start_vertex = self.vertex_data.index(start_vertex_data)
        distances = [float('inf')] * self.size
        distances[start_vertex] = 0
        visited = [False] * self.size

        for _ in range(self.size):
            min_distance = float('inf')
            u = None
            for i in range(self.size):
                if not visited[i] and distances[i] < min_distance:
                    min_distance = distances[i]
                    u = i

            if u is None:
                break

            visited[u] = True

            for v in range(self.size):
                if self.adj_matrix[u][v] != 0 and not visited[v]:
                    alt = distances[u] + self.adj_matrix[u][v]
                    if alt < distances[v]:
                        distances[v] = alt

        return distances

g = Graph(7)

g.add_vertex_data(0, 'A')
g.add_vertex_data(1, 'B')
g.add_vertex_data(2, 'C')
g.add_vertex_data(3, 'D')
g.add_vertex_data(4, 'E')
g.add_vertex_data(5, 'F')
g.add_vertex_data(6, 'G')

g.add_edge(3, 0, 4)  # D - A, weight 5
g.add_edge(3, 4, 2)  # D - E, weight 2
g.add_edge(0, 2, 3)  # A - C, weight 3
g.add_edge(0, 4, 4)  # A - E, weight 4
g.add_edge(4, 2, 4)  # E - C, weight 4
g.add_edge(4, 6, 5)  # E - G, weight 5
g.add_edge(2, 5, 5)  # C - F, weight 5
g.add_edge(2, 1, 2)  # C - B, weight 2
g.add_edge(1, 5, 2)  # B - F, weight 2
g.add_edge(6, 5, 5)  # G - F, weight 5

# Dijkstra's algorithm from D to all vertices
print("\nDijkstra's Algorithm starting from vertex D:")
distances = g.dijkstra('D')
for i, d in enumerate(distances):
    print(f"Distance from D to {g.vertex_data[i]}: {d}")

content.code_html:
class Graph:
    def __init__(self, size):
        self.adj_matrix = [[0] * size for _ in range(size)]
        self.size = size
        self.vertex_data = [''] * size

    def add_edge(self, u, v, weight):
        if 0 <= u < self.size and 0 <= v < self.size:
            self.adj_matrix[u][v] = weight
            #self.adj_matrix[v][u] = weight   For undirected graph

    def add_vertex_data(self, vertex, data):
        if 0 <= vertex < self.size:
            self.vertex_data[vertex] = data

    def dijkstra(self, start_vertex_data):
        start_vertex = self.vertex_data.index(start_vertex_data)
        distances = [float('inf')] * self.size
        distances[start_vertex] = 0
        visited = [False] * self.size

        for _ in range(self.size):
            min_distance = float('inf')
            u = None
            for i in range(self.size):
                if not visited[i] and distances[i] < min_distance:
                    min_distance = distances[i]
                    u = i

            if u is None:
                break

            visited[u] = True

            for v in range(self.size):
                if self.adj_matrix[u][v] != 0 and not visited[v]:
                    alt = distances[u] + self.adj_matrix[u][v]
                    if alt < distances[v]:
                        distances[v] = alt

        return distances

g = Graph(7)

g.add_vertex_data(0, 'A')
g.add_vertex_data(1, 'B')
g.add_vertex_data(2, 'C')
g.add_vertex_data(3, 'D')
g.add_vertex_data(4, 'E')
g.add_vertex_data(5, 'F')
g.add_vertex_data(6, 'G')

g.add_edge(3, 0, 4)  # D -> A, weight 5
g.add_edge(3, 4, 2)  # D -> E, weight 2
g.add_edge(0, 2, 3)  # A -> C, weight 3
g.add_edge(0, 4, 4)  # A -> E, weight 4
g.add_edge(4, 2, 4)  # E -> C, weight 4
g.add_edge(4, 6, 5)  # E -> G, weight 5
g.add_edge(2, 5, 5)  # C -> F, weight 5
g.add_edge(1, 2, 2)  # B -> C, weight 2
g.add_edge(1, 5, 2)  # B -> F, weight 2
g.add_edge(6, 5, 5)  # G -> F, weight 5

# Dijkstra's algorithm from D to all vertices
print("Dijkstra's Algorithm starting from vertex D:\n")
distances = g.dijkstra('D')
for i, d in enumerate(distances):
    print(f"Shortest distance from D to {g.vertex_data[i]}: {d}")

content.text: This result is similar to the previous example using Dijkstra's algorithm on the undirected graph. However, there's a key difference: in this case, vertex B cannot be visited from D, and this means that the shortest distance from D to F is now 11, not 10, because the path can no longer go through vertex B.
content.html: This result is similar to the previous example using Dijkstra's algorithm on the undirected graph. However, there's a key difference: in this case, vertex B cannot be visited from D, and this means that the shortest distance from D to F is now 11, not 10, because the path can no longer go through vertex B.

content.text: Returning The Paths from Dijkstra's Algorithm

With a few adjustments, the actual shortest paths can also be returned by Dijkstra's algorithm, in addition to the shortest path values. So for example, instead of just returning that the shortest path value is 10 from vertex D to F, the algorithm can also return that the shortest path is "D-> E-> C-> B-> F".
content.html: With a few adjustments, the actual shortest paths can also be returned by Dijkstra's algorithm, in addition to the shortest path values. So for example, instead of just returning that the shortest path value is 10 from vertex D to F, the algorithm can also return that the shortest path is "D->E->C->B->F".

content.text: To return the path, we create a predecessors array to keep the previous vertex in the shortest path for each vertex. The predecessors array can be used to backtrack to find the shortest path for every vertex.
content.html: To return the path, we create a predecessors array to keep the previous vertex in the shortest path for each vertex. The predecessors array can be used to backtrack to find the shortest path for every vertex.

content.code_html:
class Graph:
    # ... (rest of the Graph class)

    def dijkstra(self, start_vertex_data):
        start_vertex = self.vertex_data.index(start_vertex_data)
        distances = [float('inf')] * self.size
        predecessors = [None] * self.size
        distances[start_vertex] = 0
        visited = [False] * self.size

        for _ in range(self.size):
            min_distance = float('inf')
            u = None
            for i in range(self.size):
                if not visited[i] and distances[i] < min_distance:
                    min_distance = distances[i]
                    u = i

            if u is None:
                break

            visited[u] = True

            for v in range(self.size):
                if self.adj_matrix[u][v] != 0 and not visited[v]:
                    alt = distances[u] + self.adj_matrix[u][v]
                    if alt < distances[v]:
                        distances[v] = alt
                        predecessors[v] = u

        return distances, predecessors

    def get_path(self, predecessors, start_vertex, end_vertex):
        path = []
        current = self.vertex_data.index(end_vertex)
        while current is not None:
            path.insert(0, self.vertex_data[current])
            current = predecessors[current]
            if current == self.vertex_data.index(start_vertex):
                path.insert(0, start_vertex)
                break
        return '->'.join(path)  # Join the vertices with '->'

g = Graph(7)

# ... (rest of the graph setup)

# Dijkstra's algorithm from D to all vertices
print("Dijkstra's Algorithm starting from vertex D:\n")
distances, predecessors = g.dijkstra('D')
for i, d in enumerate(distances):
    path = g.get_path(predecessors, 'D', g.vertex_data[i])
    print(f"{path}, Distance: {d}")

content.text: Line 33-42: The get_path method uses the predecessors array and returns a string with the shortest path from start to end vertex.
content.html: Line 33-42: The get_path method uses the predecessors array and returns a string with the shortest path from start to end vertex.

content.text: Dijkstra's Algorithm with a Single Destination Vertex
Let's say we are only interested in finding the shortest path between two vertices, like finding the shortest distance between vertex D and vertex F in the graph below.
content.html: Let's say we are only interested in finding the shortest path between two vertices, like finding the shortest distance between vertex D and vertex F in the graph below.

content.text: Dijkstra's algorithm is normally used for finding the shortest path from one source vertex to all other vertices in the graph, but it can also be modified to only find the shortest path from the source to a single destination vertex, by just stopping the algorithm when the destination is reached (visited).
content.html: Dijkstra's algorithm is normally used for finding the shortest path from one source vertex to all other vertices in the graph, but it can also be modified to only find the shortest path from the source to a single destination vertex, by just stopping the algorithm when the destination is reached (visited).

content.text: This means that for the specific graph in the image above, Dijkstra's algorithm will stop after visiting F (the destination vertex), before visiting vertices H, I and J because they are farther away from D than F is.
content.html: This means that for the specific graph in the image above, Dijkstra's algorithm will stop after visiting F (the destination vertex), before visiting vertices H, I and J because they are farther away from D than F is.

content.text: Below we can see the status of the calculated distances when Dijkstra's algorithm has found the shortest distance from D to F, and stops running.
content.html: Below we can see the status of the calculated distances when Dijkstra's algorithm has found the shortest distance from D to F, and stops running.

content.text: In the image above, vertex F has just got updated with distance 10 from vertex B. Since F is the unvisited vertex with the lowest distance from D, it would normally be the next current vertex, but since it is the destination, the algorithm stops. If the algorithm did not stop, J would be the next vertex to get an updated distance 11+2=13, from vertex I.
content.html: In the image above, vertex F has just got updated with distance 10 from vertex B. Since F is the unvisited vertex with the lowest distance from D, it would normally be the next current vertex, but since it is the destination, the algorithm stops. If the algorithm did not stop, J would be the next vertex to get an updated distance 11+2=13, from vertex I.

content.code_html:
class Graph:
    # ... (existing methods)

    def dijkstra(self, start_vertex_data, end_vertex_data):
        start_vertex = self.vertex_data.index(start_vertex_data)
        end_vertex = self.vertex_data.index(end_vertex_data)
        distances = [float('inf')] * self.size
        predecessors = [None] * self.size
        distances[start_vertex] = 0
        visited = [False] * self.size

        for _ in range(self.size):
            min_distance = float('inf')
            u = None
            for i in range(self.size):
                if not visited[i] and distances[i] < min_distance:
                    min_distance = distances[i]
                    u = i

            if u is None or u == end_vertex:
                print(f"Breaking out of loop. Current vertex: {self.vertex_data[u]}")
                print(f"Distances: {distances}")
                break

            visited[u] = True
            print(f"Visited vertex: {self.vertex_data[u]}")

            for v in range(self.size):
                if self.adj_matrix[u][v] != 0 and not visited[v]:
                    alt = distances[u] + self.adj_matrix[u][v]
                    if alt < distances[v]:
                        distances[v] = alt
                        predecessors[v] = u

        return distances[end_vertex], self.get_path(predecessors, start_vertex_data, end_vertex_data)

# Example usage
g = Graph(7)
# ... (rest of the graph setup)
distance, path = g.dijkstra('D', 'F')
print(f"Path: {path}, Distance: {distance}")

content.text: Line 20-23: If we are about to choose the destination vertex as the current vertex and mark it as visited, it means we have already calculated the shortest distance to the destination vertex, and Dijkstra's algorithm can be stopped in this single destination case.
content.html: Line 20-23: If we are about to choose the destination vertex as the current vertex and mark it as visited, it means we have already calculated the shortest distance to the destination vertex, and Dijkstra's algorithm can be stopped in this single destination case.

content.text: Time Complexity for Dijkstra's Algorithm
With V V as the number of vertices in our graph, the time complexity for Dijkstra's algorithm is
content.html: With VV as the number of vertices in our graph, the time complexity for Dijkstra's algorithm is

content.text: O ( V 2 ) O ( V 2 )
content.html: O(V2)O(V2)

content.text: The reason why we get this time complexity is that the vertex with the lowest distance must to be search for to choose the next current vertex, and that takes O ( V ) O ( V ) time. And since this must to be done for every vertex connected to the source, we need to factor that in, and so we get time complexity O ( V 2 ) O ( V 2 ) for Dijkstra's algorithm.
content.html: The reason why we get this time complexity is that the vertex with the lowest distance must to be search for to choose the next current vertex, and that takes O(V)O(V) time. And since this must to be done for every vertex connected to the source, we need to factor that in, and so we get time complexity O(V2)O(V2) for Dijkstra's algorithm.

content.text: By using a Min-heap or Fibonacci-heap data structure for the distances instead (not yet explained in this tutorial), the time needed to search for the minimum distance vertex is reduced from O ( V ) O ( V ) to O ( log V ) O ( log ⁡ V ) , which results in an improved time complexity for Dijkstra's algorithm
content.html: By using a Min-heap or Fibonacci-heap data structure for the distances instead (not yet explained in this tutorial), the time needed to search for the minimum distance vertex is reduced from O(V)O(V) to O(logV)O(log⁡V), which results in an improved time complexity for Dijkstra's algorithm

content.text: O ( V ⋅ log V + E ) O ( V ⋅ log ⁡ V + E )
content.html: O(V⋅logV+E)O(V⋅log⁡V+E)

content.text: Where V V is the number of vertices in the graph, and E E is the number of edges.
content.html: Where VV is the number of vertices in the graph, and EE is the number of edges.

content.text: The improvement we get from using a Min-heap data structure for Dijkstra's algorithm is especially good if we have a large and sparse graph, which means a graph with a large number of vertices, but not as many edges.
content.html: The improvement we get from using a Min-heap data structure for Dijkstra's algorithm is especially good if we have a large and sparse graph, which means a graph with a large number of vertices, but not as many edges.

content.text: The implementation of Dijkstra's algorithm with the Fibonacci-heap data structure is better for dense graphs, where each vertex has an edge to almost every other vertex.
content.html: The implementation of Dijkstra's algorithm with the Fibonacci-heap data structure is better for dense graphs, where each vertex has an edge to almost every other vertex.
